com.ausregistry.jtoolkit2.session

Class Transaction

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ausregistry.jtoolkit2.session.Transaction

  • public class Transaction
extends java.lang.Object
    Each EPP command/response pair is modelled as a Transaction. A Transaction associates a Response with a Command to enable the user to determine the effect of each command. The SessionManager takes either a single Transaction or an array of Transactions as an argument to SessionManager.execute(com.ausregistry.jtoolkit2.session.Transaction).

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Transaction(Command command, Response response)
      Create a Transaction from the given command/response pair.

      The interval of time (in milliseconds) that elapsed between when the start method was executed and when the transaction completed, as determined by a change in transaction state.

      Get the current state of this Transaction.

      • getCommand

        public Command getCommand()

      • getResponse

      • getState

        public TransactionState getState()
        Get the current state of this Transaction.
        See Also:
        SessionManagerImpl.execute(Transaction[]), TransactionState

      • setState

        public void setState(TransactionState state)
        Indicate the new state of this Transaction. This should not generally be used by the application - rather a SessionManager usually invokes this so that the application may determine the state using getState().

      • getCause

        public java.lang.Throwable getCause()
        Get the cause of failure of this Transaction.

      • setCause

        public void setCause(java.lang.Throwable cause)
        Indicate the cause of failure of this Transaction. Similarly to setState(TransactionState), the application should not generally use this.

      • start

        public void start()
        Indicate that the transaction is now in progress.

      • getResponseTime

        public long getResponseTime()
        The interval of time (in milliseconds) that elapsed between when the start method was executed and when the transaction completed, as determined by a change in transaction state.
